Award.AwardTitle: CSforAll: EAGER: Integrating Lightweight Data Science and Computing for K-12

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Brown University proposes to create lightweight data science curricula for K-12. Data science can be roughly defined as "programming + statistics" and thus has two points of control: how much programming is needed, and how much statistics is used. The term "lightweight" here is not used pejoratively but to connote an approach that is aligned with the CS for All Initiative's goal of scaling CS education to all schools and all students. This project will limit mathematics to "na√Øve" statistics rather than depending on continuous mathematics. For programming, the curriculum will create support that requires no more sophistication than required by CS Principles curricula, and perhaps even less. Finally, it will also be light on setup, using Google Sheets as the primary "database" system, lifting a big administrative burden on teachers and schools, and enabling elegant user interfaces that are already familiar to many students and teachers.

The programming support will be embedded into Pyret, a pedagogic programming language, extending it with direct support for tables and tabular operations. This will allow students to write concise programs using constructs designed to be evocative of SQL. To increase access to younger students and to limit typing, the PIs will incorporate a dual-mode block-and-text interface into Pyret. In order to engage more students, the work will include support for curricular personalization, allowing students to pick out the topics that they are interested in, and find the corresponding questions they want to ask about these data. The PIs will provide curated datasets, as well as means for teachers to find other similar data, to help students who need suggestions to get started. Finally, building on previous work of the PI and others, project will involve some preliminary investigation on whether providing high-level constructs and letting teachers teach "to the constructs" will naturally lead to better plan composition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data science is a major new mode of generating knowledge. The application of computing to data, mediated by statistics, can generate new hypotheses and insights, though it can also carry perils when these methods are mis-applied. Due to the increasingly availability of data in almost every human endeavor, numerous areas stand to be revolutionized by this form of thinking. Furthermore, this team believes that just about every child — even one who claims to "hate math" — is inherently a data scientist: just ask them to argue for the superiority of their favorite player or singer or app or other object with personal meaning, and they will routinely reach out to find numbers to justify their claim. How can we tap this latent potential?

This grant supported the Bootstrap:Data Science Project, an effort to create an integrated curriulum by injecting computing into contexts that work with data. These can range across fields as diverse as math, statistics, business, economics, social studies, and more. An integrated setting, however, requires great care: teachers in such a setting are usually not trained in computing and may not even be especially interested in learning and teaching it. Therefore, any computing content needs to be very carefully designed to the particular needs and constraints of such a setting.

The work on this grant focused on the programming and tooling support needed for such integration. It involved programming language design, library design, implementation, and tooling. Some of the work was more foundational, such as the design of a language-integrated query language. Other work was more practical but nevertheless critical, such as integrating Google Sheets as a familiar and useful "database" mechanism. Attention to a combination of such factors has enabled the curriculum to see growing interest and use.

The intellectual merit rests on the language design principles. In particular, the team has experimented with a variety of designs for lightweight programming support: custom query languages, functions, and methods, and comparing their affordances. This has generated several insights into this topic, which is rarely studied in the programming language and software engineering communities.

The broader impact lies in the materials produced, disseminated, and used. The team has made all its software and curriculum available for free. The software routinely gets over 100 active users/day, which is an indication of its growing popularity.
